Diwali or Tihar, the festival of lights, is a five-day Hindu festival celebrated in Nepal that is dedicated to the worship of the Hindu goddess of wealth, Laxmi.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
The festival brings together the key aspects of nature - people, animals and colours. As part of the celebrations, cows, crows, dogs and oxen are worshipped across the country symbolising the manifestation of various gods.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
On the Kukur (dog) Tihar day, the Nepalese Hindu community worships dogs owing to their religious significance as the guard of Lord Yama, the god of death. It is also believed that dogs can lead the souls of the dead to heaven.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Dogs üê∂ are offered special prayers with tikka, garlands and delicious foods. We have compiled several images of dogs being honoured for their role as man's best friend in providing companionship and security.‚Å†‚†Ä

‚ÄúWe were kept chained after work, sometimes for days even, in a dark room without food.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä

More than four million people, including children, work in almost 20,000 brick kilns across Pakistan to pay off family loans taken from business owners.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Children often inherit their parents‚Äô debts and become bonded as individuals for a long time. If the parents leave the kiln, the children are kept as hostages.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
In Pakistan, it is illegal to employ someone under 16 years of age. But almost 70 percent of bonded labourers in Pakistan are children. They work all day and have no access to education.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

"People die inside the greenhouse because they have no protection ‚Ä¶ Consumers are not aware that we are slaves inside the greenhouse," says Spitou Mendy, union chairman and a greenhouse worker in Almeria, Spain.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Almeria's greenhouses are a sprawling, futuristic farming model of structural symmetry cultivating produce by the metric tonne in a land where water is scarce, the earth scorched and the sun blinding.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
In reality, what is referred to as Almeria's "economic miracle" is almost exclusively dependant on invisible, expendable and often illegally employed migrant workers toiling under 40-degree heat and extreme humidity.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
"In the end, the worker is sacrificed so that a well-packaged product reaches the supermarkets."‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
On World Food Day, Al Jazeera looks at the processes behind the food we eat every day.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

Polls have opened across Mozambique for presidential, parliamentary and provincial elections.‚Å†‚†Ä

.‚Å†‚†Ä
For the first time, Mozambicans are also electing provincial governors, a key concession to Renamo. Previously all governors were appointed by the ruling party.‚Å†‚†Ä

Over 400,000 tourists enjoyed hot air balloon tours in Turkey's charming touristic hub of Cappadocia between January and September, according to data compiled by the Anadolu news agency.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Cappadocia, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is famous for its distinctive plateau, valleys, hills, unique "fairy chimney" volcanic cones, colourful frescos covering underground cities, houses carved into rocks, rock churches, chapels, and shelters used by the early Christians.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
A one-hour hot air balloon ride over Cappadocia costs $186 to $220 per person. The tours generated $86m in revenue in the first nine months of this year, the data showed.‚Å†‚†Ä

Waving flags and snapping selfies, thousands of Iranian women on Thursday entered a football stadium to watch a match in person for the first time in decades, after FIFA threatened to suspend the country over its controversial stadium restrictions.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
"We are so happy that finally, we got the chance to go to the stadium. It's an extraordinary feeling," Zahra Pashaei, a 29-year-old nurse who has only seen football games on television, told the Associated Press news agency. "At least for me, 22 or 23 years of longing and regret lies behind this.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
For nearly 40 years, Iran has barred female spectators from entering football and other sports stadiums, as Muslim leaders argued that women must be shielded from the masculine ambience and sight of semi-clad men.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Last month, world football's governing body FIFA pressured Iran to allow women unrestricted access to stadiums and provide enough tickets to meet the demand.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
That came after the death of Sahar Khodayari, dubbed the "Blue Girl" because of the colours of the football club she supported, who set herself ablaze last month outside a court after she found out that she could face a two-year jail sentence for attempting to enter a stadium dressed as a boy.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

"I feel sorry for him. His parents don't want to leave (Sibilyakovo) yet and it's scary to send a little boy like him over the Irtysh (River), there are such big waves," says teacher Uminur Kuchukova, 61.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Kuchukova has taught for 42 years in the village of Sibilyakovo, Omsk region, Russia. She could have retired years ago but has stayed for the sake of the school's last pupil, nine-year-old Ravil Izhmukhametov.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
When Kuchukova leaves next year, the school will close.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Ravil said he has no interest in moving to the city, but he realises he will have to one day. Asked what school was like without any classmates, he said: "I've got nothing to compare it to, but of course I'd like to have friends so I'm looking forward to going to the main school."‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Like thousands of villages dotted across Russia, the remote Siberian village of Sibilyakovo emptied after the closure of its state-run collective farm following the 1991 collapse of the Soviet planned economy. ‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
In its heyday in the 1970s, Sibilyakovo's primary school had four classes, each with about 18 children.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

Rescue pilot Kiran Pun has been flying Nepal's mountain routes since 1995. With a bird's eye view of the Himalayas, pilots have a unique perspective of the landscape and can see the effect climate change is having on Mount Everest's glaciers and the surrounding mountains.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
"I've noticed great changes in the size of glaciers on the mountains due to global warming," says Pun. "The glaciers keep thinning and it's becoming more common to see parts of the mountains which used to be hidden by ice."‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Nepal's glaciers are melting at faster rates than in previous decades, contributing to an increase in cloud cover and rainfall over the mountains. Pilots must navigate sudden changes in weather and mountain peaks hidden by low cloud cover as they increase in altitude towards Everest.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

"A dengue outbreak is not exactly a new phenomenon. We have seen this happen every four to five years and it is often linked to changing weather patterns," said Rabindra Abeyasinghe, Philippines representative for the World Health Organization (WHO). But higher temperatures and longer rainy seasons contribute to the scale of the outbreak, he added.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Over the past months, the Philippines has been grappling to stem its worst dengue outbreak since 2012.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
According to the Department of Health, a total of 271,480 dengue cases were reported from January to August 31, 2019. As of August 31, there have been an estimated 1,107 confirmed deaths, prompting the declaration of a national dengue epidemic.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
In reaction, the health department has intensified its dengue prevention campaign, destroying mosquito breeding sites and ensuring adequate blood supply in hospitals.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Dengue infection is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which is common in all parts of the Philippines. Patients exhibit flu-like symptoms with a fever that runs for two to seven days.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

"Many thought it was a bad idea. Others laughed at me. My own family advised me against [it] - but it is the best business decision I have ever made," says Zamzam Yusuf, a camel trader in Somalia. She's breaking down barriers in a job often reserved for men in the conservative country in the Horn of Africa.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
"When men found out what I do, they told me it is not a woman's job. That it is too difficult and I should leave it to them," says Zamzam, a mother of seven.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Tired with life in London where she worked as a carer for more than 10 years, the 55-year-old decided to return home three years ago and now has 145 camels.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Of the world's estimated 35 million camels, Somalia, a country of more than 15 million people, houses more than seven million camels - the highest number per country globally.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Livestock is the backbone of the Somali economy with more than 65 percent of the population engaged in some way in the industry, according to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. But it is rare to see a woman at any of the busy camel markets in the East African country.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

Every year in September Russia üá∑üá∫ relives the 2004 nightmare of the deadliest "terrorist" attack in its modern history: the Beslan school siege in which more than 300 people died.‚Å†
.‚Å†
Here's how it unfolded: On the morning of September 1, 2004, teachers, students and their families gathered in front of School Number One in the town of Beslan, North Ossetia to celebrate the start of the new school year.‚Å†
.‚Å†
First, they heard gunfire, and then they saw a group of armed men forcing people into the school building.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The rebels took approximately 1,200 children and adults hostage at the school, without providing food or water for three days.‚Å†
.‚Å†
On the first day, they executed a man in front of his two children and the other hostages. Later they took a group of men at gunpoint in a classroom on the first floor, shot them and threw their bodies out of the window.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The attackers - members of a Chechen separatist group called Riyad as-Saliheen Martyrs‚Äô Brigade - demanded the recognition of Chechnya‚Äôs independence from Russia and the immediate withdrawal of Russian troops from the region.‚Å†
.‚Å†
On the third day of the standoff, local authorities received permission from the attackers to remove the bodies lying in front of the school. But when medical workers approached the building, two of them were shot dead, followed by two explosions 20 seconds later.‚Å†
.‚Å†
The siege ended with 334 hostages dead, more than half of whom were children. The only attacker caught alive was sentenced to life in prison.‚Å†
.‚Å†

Iceland commemorated the passing of Okjokull, its first glacier lost to climate change, as scientists warn that some 400 others on the subarctic island risk the same fate.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
As the world recently marked the warmest July ever on record, a bronze plaque was mounted on a bare rock, where once the glacier existed, in a ceremony in western Iceland, attended by local researchers and their peers at Rice University in the United States who initiated the project.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
The plaque - bearing the inscription "A letter to the future" - is intended to raise awareness about the decline of glaciers and the effects of climate change.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
"In the next 200 years, all our glaciers are expected to follow the same path. This monument is to acknowledge that we know what is happening and what needs to be done. Only you know if we did it," the plaque reads.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Iceland loses about 11 billion tonnes of ice per year, and scientists fear all of the island's 400-plus glaciers will be gone by 2200. Glaciers cover about 11 percent of the country's surface.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

"Our oceans are on the verge of collapse and we have all played a role in this. Now we must all play our part to stop it,‚Äù said Javier Bardem, Oscar-winning actor and Antarctic ambassador for Greenpeace during his address to UN delegates at the Global Ocean Treaty negotiations.‚Å†‚†Ä

These were the days that defined a generation ‚òÆÔ∏è.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Fifty years ago, mid-August, a music and arts festival named Woodstock took place in a 600-acre pasture near Bethel, New York. Its popular culture fingerprint was so strong that it defined the "Woodstock generation."‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
To some Americans, the pivotal festival of "peace and music" 50 years ago was an inspiring moment of countercultural community and youthful freethinking. To others, it was an outrageous display of indulgence, moral decay and insouciance in a time of war. To still others, it was just a world apart from theirs.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Around 400.000 people attended. Despite scores of drug arrests, thousands of medical problems and two deaths, one from a heroin overdose and another when a teen was run over, there were no reports of violence.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
üé∏ On stage, there were some of the biggest rock legends: Jimi Hendrix, Santana, Joe Cocker, The Who, Janis Joplin, Joan Baez, Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Creedence Clearwater Revival, Riche Havens, Ten Years After, Jefferson Airplane, Ravi Shankar, and more.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä
Fifty years later, memories of the rainy weekend of August 15-18, 1969 remain sharp among people who were in the crowd and on the stage. ‚ùï Do you have a memory of Woodstock? Have you heard tales? Read about it or watched? Do you like the music? Comment to let us know what Woodstock is to you today, half a century later.‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

In 2008, a Shell oil pipeline that ran under the creeks of Bodo Village, Nigeria üá≥üá¨, exploded. The burst lasted for 77 days, devastating the diverse ecosystem and destroying local fisheries and farms. ‚Å†‚†Ä
.‚Å†‚†Ä

‚ÄúThat agreement which has been signed specifies that there will be five members from each side in the sovereign council which will effectively be the presidency of the country and there will be members nominated from the Forces of Freedom and Change to the executive council, which will be made up of ministers.

‚ÄúIt doesn't state how this transitional government will be running, it doesn't explain what roles the sovereign council and executive council will have. That will be defined in the constitutional declaration, which according to an AU envoy, will be signed on Friday."

.

"If the locusts come in large numbers, then it is unlikely that any of the crop will survive. The locusts will not rise until they have completely eaten the crop," says Azmatullah, a 45-year-old farmer in the southern Pakistani province of Sindh.
.
He is among the thousands of farmers who cultivate more than 246,000 hectares of cotton, nearly 23 percent of Pakistan's entire crop.
.
Pakistan is the fourth-largest producer of cotton in the world, and its third-largest consumer. Any threat to the cotton crop could be catastrophic, especially for the country's already stagnant exports.
.
For the past month, authorities have been battling a swarm of desert locusts which has been threatening the country's main cash crop, at a time when Pakistan is already going through a major economic crisis, with slowing growth, a skyrocketing exchange rate and rising inflation.
.
The war in Yemen has prevented its authorities from controlling the insects, which now threaten Pakistani agriculture.
.

This is what Mosul looks like two years after ISIL's defeat.

More than 300,000 residents of Mosul district are still displaced with no homes to go back to, two years since the end of the military operation to retake the city from Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) armed group. "How to tell the history of humanity without the earliest of old chapters, Babylon?"
.
Iraq's üáÆüá∂ representative to UNESCO's World Heritage Committee wondered what is the world heritage list without Babylon.
.
In the vote that followed, UNESCO voted to list the sprawling Mesopotamian metropolis of Babylon as a World Heritage Site.
.
It took three decades of lobbying efforts by Iraq. The country had been trying since 1983 to have the site - a massive 10sq-km complex of which just 18 percent has been excavated thus far - recognised by UNESCO.
.
Babylon developed as a walled city of mudbrick temples and towers, known internationally for its hanging gardens, the Tower of Babel, and the Ishtar Gate.
.
It is one of 7,000 archaeological sites across Iraq, many of which were destroyed by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant group (ISIS or ISIL) or ravaged by lucrative artefact smuggling.
.
Several Iraqi antiquities were also looted after the US invasion in 2003, and according to a report by the British Museum, the invasion caused widespread damage and severe contamination to the remains of the ancient city.
.

Millions at risk as #India's sixth-biggest city runs out of water.

The city of #Chennai in Tamil Nadu state is now virtually out of water, while it has been hitting temperatures over 41C.

Millions of people have been forced to rely on water from tank trucks in the southern Tamil Nadu, which had a 62 percent shortfall in monsoon rains last year.

While 70 percent of India‚Äôs population depends on agriculture, 75 percent of #water required for the fields comes from the southwest monsoon. Water storage in reservoirs appears insufficient for irrigation and drinking supplies and boreholes down to the groundwater are commonplace.

The increasing population, increase in irrigation requirements, the need for drinking water and deficient #monsoon rains have obvious consequences. Boreholes are drawn on for greater supply and the groundwater level consequently drops even further.

"It's really amazing how the human mind and body can adapt to new environments. How the once incredible can become so normal," tweeted Anne McClain of NASA four days before starting her journey back from the 58/59 expedition on the International Space Agency.

She touched down safely with both Oleg Kononenko from the Russian Space Agency; Roscosmos, and David Saint-Jacques from the Canadian Space Agency.

They landed abroad Russia‚Äôs Soyuz MS-11 spacecraft four days ago in a remote area in Kazakhstan.

During the six months of their expedition, the crewmembers helped conducting hundreds of experiments and overhang the arrival and departure of several robotic resupply ships.

Their departure left behind cosmonaut Aleksey Ovchinin of Roscosmos and NASA astronauts Christina Koch and Nick Hague to begin Expedition 60.

Soyuz MS-11 was the 57th Russian Soyuz spacecraft to fly to the International Space Station. It traveled a total of 86.4 million miles (139 million kilometers) over the course of 3,264 orbits of Earth. "I encourage all humans to do something out of your comfort zone that forces you to adapt. You'll be pleasantly surprised of your capabilities." Says Anne McClain.

Chinese couples used to be satisfied with a single black and white photograph taken on their #wedding as a memento of their special day.

But times have changed dramatically, and the wedding photographs, especially pre-wedding #photo sessions, have become big business in China. In the main touristic spots in different cities across China, it is easy to see couples having their pre-wedding pictures shoots, which becomes the must-have for every #Chinese #couple before their marriage.

Unlike Western #weddings, where usually couples have their photos taken on the wedding day, for the Chinese it is quite popular to have their day-long photo sessions way before their actual weddings. Sometimes it can be half a year or even a year in advance of the ceremony.

These sessions can range in price from a few hundred up to thousands of #dollars, with companies providing clients with everything from outfits to make up and transportation. #Brides typically have at least three dress changes per shoot.

Japan's government maintains that eating whale is a cherished part of its food culture. Nationwide consumption peaked in the early 1960s before falling as other protein sources became cheaply available.

'Living in the Unknown,' @contrast.vr's latest #VR film, highlights the fears and hopes of Uighur Muslims who have made it to Turkey.
.
Uighur Muslims are ethnic Turks that call the Xinjiang province in western China üá®üá≥ home. Human rights groups claim that around a million of them and other ethnic minorities are held in so called ‚Äòconcentration camps‚Äô there.
.
China, on the other hand, claims the accusations are baseless and politically motivated. The Chinese government insists it‚Äôs fighting separatism and religious extremism in the region and that the facilities are vocational training centers needed for Uighurs who are vulnerable to dangerous ideas.
.
Many Uighur Muslims are fleeing the Xinjiang province. Thousands have escaped to Istanbul, Turkey, where they feel they can freely practice their religion and foster their culture. However, most of them struggle to get in touch with their loved ones back in China and have no idea whether they are safe or imprisoned.
.
As they go about their day in Istanbul, the characters of 'Living in the Unknown' share what it means to live without knowing anything about their loved ones even though communication over the phone, such as instant text messaging, is as widely used in other parts of the world as ever before. .

Sudan's üá∏üá© former President Omar al-Bashir has appeared in public for the first time since his overthrow by the military following months of mass protests against 30-years of his autocratic rule.

Fishermen like Jose da Cruz have made their living for decades hunting for crabs among #Brazil's vast coastal mangrove forests, dense thickets of twisted plants in deep black mud that grow where fresh-water rivers meet the brackish #Atlantic Ocean.

Cruz, who is known by the nickname Vampire because of his distinctive teeth, doesn't use a rod and reel or a net. Instead he parks his two-foot-wide boat at the shore of the #Caratingui river and wends his way on foot through the tangle of #mangroves to dig out crabs with his hands from the dark muck.

WWII #veterans gather at memorial landmarks across Normandy on #Thursday to mark the 75th anniversary of the D-Day landings.

In the early hours of June 6, 1944, waves of allied troops set off from Portsmouth, #England and the surrounding area to begin the air, sea and land assault on Normandy that ultimately led to the liberation of Western #Europe from the Nazis.

The invasion, codenamed Operation Overlord and commanded by #US General Dwight D Eisenhower, remains the largest amphibious assault in history and involved almost 7,000 ships and landing craft and 156,000 troops along an 80km stretch of the #French coast.

A series of bombings has hit luxury hotels and churches in¬†#SriLanka, killing at least 160 people and wounding over 400 as worshippers were attending #Easter #Sunday services.

Three of the explosions took place in #Catholic churches while three other explosions were reported in luxury #hotels - the Cinnamon Grand, #Kingsbury and Shangri-La - located in the heart of #Colombo.

The first explosion was reported in a church located in the capital. The other blasts followed within half an hour.

There were no immediate claims of responsibility.

Afaf Hussein, 10, from the village of al-Jaraib, in the northwestern province of Hajjah, #Yemen is severely malnourished.

Afaf, who now weighs around 11 kg and is described by her #doctor as "skin and bones", has been left acutely malnourished by a limited diet during her growing years and suffering from hepatitis, likely caused by infected water. She left #school two years ago because she got too weak.

As Yeman‚Äôs war grinds into its fifth year with peace efforts stalling, ten-year-old Afaf‚Äôs father sees little hope he will be able to give his starving daughter the food or healthcare she needs.

Four years of conflict have pushed Yemen, which was already one of the poorest #Arab states, to the brink of famine. War has cut transport routes for aid, fuel and #food, reduced imports and caused severe inflation.

The United Nations says about 80 percent of the population needs some form of humanitarian assistance and two-thirds of all districts in the country are in a ‚Äúpre-famine‚Äù state.

Twins are common in the Yoruba ethnic group that dominates this part of #Nigeria.

On the 25th anniversary of Rwandan üá∑üáº genocide, residents in Mabare village share stories of survival, heroism and tragedy.

For the first days of the genocide, Mabare, a Hutu majority village, was spared. People in the village continued to tend to their farms as usual.

But then bodies, some peppered with bullets, started floating in the waters of the nearby Lake Mugesera.

Led by the imam of their only mosque, Rashid Bagabo, the residents decided to act.

Using his small boat, the imam began collecting the bodies from the lake while young men from his mosque set up barriers at the two unpaved roads that cut through their village in a bid to obstruct the attackers' access.

Slowly, the doors of the mosque filled up - young and old, men and women, Muslims and Christians all took shelter. | Check our website for the story | üì∑ Photos: @hamza_africa for Al Jazeera English | .

‚ÄúMy mission is to tell you the story and then you decide what you want to do,‚Äù Yannis Behrakis told a panel discussing Reuters Pulitzer Prize-winning photo series on the European migrant crisis. ‚ÄúMy mission is to make sure that nobody can say: ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt know‚Äô.‚Äù
.
Behrakis was one of the most iconic news photographers of our time. He passed away today after a long battle with cancer. He was 58.
.
For three decades with Reuters, he made thousands of images across Europe, Russia, the Middle East, Africa and Asia, covering violence and upheaval.

He covered many of the most tumultuous events around the world, including conflicts in Afghanistan and Chechnya, a huge earthquake in Kashmir and the Egyptian uprising of 2011.

Some of his best work on the field was his coverage of the migrant crisis from Greece.

The first picture in this carousel, one of Behrakis' best images, was shot in Eidomeni, Greece. It was that of  Syrian refugee carrying and kissing his daughter as he walked down a road in the rain. ‚ÄúI would love to be this father; I think every child would love to have a father like this," Behrakis said. "This picture proves that there are superheroes after all. He doesn‚Äôt wear a red cape, but he has a black plastic cape made out of garbage bags. For me this represents the universal father and the unconditional love of father to daughter.‚Äù (photos: @yannisbehrakis, @reuters )

Qatar¬†has stunned four-time champions #Japan winning with the score of 3-1 in the final of the #AFC Asian Cup held in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Hosts #UAE, along with #Saudi Arabia, #Bahrain and #Egypt severed all diplomatic and economic ties with Doha, imposing a land, sea and air blockade on the Gulf nation in June 2017.

The Maroons had to take a longer route via Kuwait to get to the tournament, an air journey that took more than five hours when a direct flight would take under an hour.

Playing against the backdrop of the regional political dispute and without any fans in the stands, #Qatar beat Saudi Arabia 2-0 in a group match and then thrashed UAE 4-0 in a semi-final that saw shoes and bottles hurled at #Qatari players.

A pedestrian stops to take a photo by #Chicago River, as bitter cold phenomenon called the polar vortex has descended on much of the central and eastern United States, in Chicago US.

A torrent of polar air brought record-low temperatures to much of the US Midwest on #Wednesday, making conditions so unbearable that trash haulers stopped making pickups and mail carriers suspended deliveries.

Classes were canceled for Wednesday and #Thursday in many cities, including Chicago, home of the nation's third-largest school system, and police warned of the risk of accidents on icy highways.

Hundreds of #flights, more than half of those scheduled, were canceled on Wednesday out of Chicago O'Hare and Chicago Midway international #airports, according to the flight tracking site FlightAware.

Photo by Pinar Istek / @reuters

Cemetery workers prepare burial sites for the victims from the collapsed dam in #Brumadinho, #Brazil on Tuesday, Jan. 29, 2019.

.

The police routinely raid the forest and take them to the south of the country, where they beg on the streets to save up just about enough to return to this forest hoping to reach #Europe .

More than 2,000 migrants have died while attempting to cross the #Mediterranean this year.

This group of South Sudanese are re-enacting scenes from their past as part of a #trauma awareness workshop in #Juba, South Sudan, to learn about how they can identify and work towards healing their own trauma.

Police protect a migrant shelter as demonstrators protest the presence of thousands of Central American migrants in #Tijuana, #Mexico, Sunday, Nov. 18, 2018.

As hundreds of rescue workers sifted through the rubble in the affected areas, the remains of five more people were found on Saturday, including four in the decimated town of Paradise and one in nearby Concow.

Northern California's Camp Fire has destroyed nearly 10,000 homes and torched 233 square miles (603 square kilometers). It is 55 percent contained.

A military operation by a #US-backed Kurdish coalition against the last pockets of ISIL in northeast #Syria seems far from ending soon.

Civilians in the area are paying the highest price. There are more than 255,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) from Deir ez-Zor province living outside the area, under control of the Syrian #army.

During the nine-month battle to retake Iraq's Mosul from the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (#ISIL) fighters, 54,000 houses were destroyed in and around the city.

A fund of $400m was established in 2015 to help #Iraq's reconstruction.

However, in 2018, the Governor of Nineveh Governorate, Nofal Hammadi, claimed to have received nothing from the fund.

The school has struggled to find qualified #teachers willing to live and work far away from major cities, but a close network of teachers and family members have come forward to help the students.

900 children were released from the armed forces in South Sudan in 2018, the country with one of the largest number of child soldiers in the world.

Encounters, killings, stone pelting and protests have become a daily affair in India-administered #Kashmir, with the toll on human lives spiking in past two years.

More and more young boys join the armed resistance against the Indian rule, with some reports saying at least 250 youth have turned #rebels since the summer of 2016.

Imagine someone removing all of his teeth in order to put 496 straws in his mouth. Or delivering #pizza from New Delhi to London and then from London to Washington and San Francisco, all within 27 hours. Or covering his body in #tattoos, including hundreds of images of maps and portraits, such as Queen Elizabeth II and Barack Obama.

The 76-year-old's name was first listed in 1990, when he rode across #India for 1,001 hours non-stop on a scooter from April 22 to June 3, covering a distance of 30,965km.

He is currently expecting a certificate for writing the longest will in the world, spanning more than 9,500 pages.

Mongolia‚Äôs vast grasslands have fallen into decline.

Nearly 80 percent of the people living on these islands are poor, with little access to basic #health and #education facilities.

The char areas have one of the highest infant mortality and maternal mortality rates in the state. It takes between 4-6 hours for a patient from char areas to reach a district #hospital for treatment in the absence of emergency medical services.

Violence has continued to spread in the Central African Republic (CAR) where over a million people - half of the country‚Äôs population - have been displaced since President Francois Bozize was overthrown in 2013.

The violence started from a sectarian conflict between the nation‚Äôs Muslim and Christian populations but has since turned into battles between disparate armed groups over resources and territory.

As the #WFP distributes food to the displaced people in Paoa in the north, the #UN has asked for $515m this year to reach all those in need across #CAR.

Abdul Hussain, 95, is a #Rohingya 
#refugee, he lives in an overcrowded refugee camp in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh.

Last August, the government of Myanmar launched a brutal crackdown on the Rohingya in Rakhine State.

Some 700,000 Rohingya have fled Rakhine to Bangladesh since then.

Most of them now live in overcrowded, squalid refugee camps on the border.

Nearly every Rohingya refugee has a story that is nothing less than a nightmare.

The violence is described as a ‚Äútextbook example of ethnic cleansing‚Äù by the UN, which has documented allegations of widespread killings, sexual violence and other abuse.

What is happening in Myanmar has spared none of the Rohingya; not the elderly, not the women, and not the children.

They all had to leave their homes and the lives they know, many leaving behind loved ones killed in the violence.

How they will rebuild their lives and what future generations have to look forward to remains a mystery as the world watches this catastrophe unfold.

Photo by @showkat_shafi for AlJazeera

An injured boy cries as he flees an area where air strikes hit a house in Saada, Yemen.

Since then, more than 10,000 people have been killed, millions have been forced to flee and the country has been ravaged by disease and hunger.

A child and a man in hospital in the besieged town of Douma, Eastern Ghouta, Damascus, Syria. 
Ongoing attacks by Syrian government forces and their allies has created "hell on Earth" for civilians stuck in a rebel-held Damascus suburb, the UN's chief said on Monday, as air strikes and ground operations continued despite a days-old ceasefire.

At least 16 people have been killed since Monday morning in Eastern Ghouta's Douma, local activist Alaa al-Ahmed told Al Jazeera from the enclave.

A day earlier, at least 27 people in the Damascus suburb died as a result of shelling by Russian-backed Syrian warplanes.

Last week, deadly air strikes and artillery fire launched by Syrian forces and their allies exacerbated a dire humanitarian crisis in the besieged enclave, home to some 400,000 people.

Photo by Bassam Khabieh / @reuters
